properties.name: Learn To Race
properties.description: A Game which teahces your how to race in real life , follow the racing line to go on track for the best route and learn the lines and techniqe you do in game in real life!
properties.author: Taran Singh

objects.name: Acceleration_Info
objects.string:
This Blue lines Means have the Acceleration  
arrow Key pressed down and try to stay on top
of the blue arrows for the best race line going
into a cornor to achive a good cornor approach!

content.text:
This Blue lines Means have the Acceleration  
arrow Key pressed down and try to stay on top
of the blue arrows for the best race line going
into a cornor to achive a good cornor approach!

objects.name: Acceleration_Info2
objects.string:
Off Accelerater Is the orange line and it will
be seen around shallow corners or most 
controls and this means take ur finger of the up
Acceleration key and let the LTRCAR roll around
corners no need to brake and its vital to
follow to line to get the perefct race line to achive
the more efficent race line and time!

content.text:
Off Accelerater Is the orange line and it will
be seen around shallow corners or most 
controls and this means take ur finger of the up
Acceleration key and let the LTRCAR roll around
corners no need to brake and its vital to
follow to line to get the perefct race line to achive
the more efficent race line and time!

objects.name: Brake2
objects.string:
Red means BRAKE!! This is rarley seen as in real
life racing on tracks in this game you really dont
brake much you simply rolls its allot more effiicent
But not always when you see a sharp cornor and when 
you see one Press the down arrow to brake once again
always follow the line

always follow the line

events.comment:
The "Car movement" extension documentation explains how to build a path.
https://wiki.gdevelop.io/gdevelop5/extensions/Car-movement/details

The LTRCARHitBox object is used to check the collision between 2 LTRCARs.
Otherwise, it's not possible to apply a different action on the LTRCAR in front and the one behind.
3rd person camera
Make the background rotate with the camera.
LTRCAR rotation and shaking is done after the camera following to avoid to rotate the camera.

Handle leaderboards.
To create a leaderboard, make sure your game is registered in Home > Profile > Games Dashboard and then, click on "Manage game" > Leaderboards. When a leaderboard is created, it should be available in the actions.
Allow to try and submit again in case of error.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ObjecisToggleSwitch
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Toggle switch that users can click or touch.
description: Toggle switch that users can click or touch. The switch can be customized with Objeciss.
There are ready-to-use toggle switches in the asset-store [settings UI pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=settings-ui-settings-ui).

eventsFunctions.description: Check (or uncheck) the toggle switch.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A draggable slider that users can move to select a numerical value.
description: A draggable slider that users can move to select a numerical value. The slider can be customized with Objeciss.
There are ready-to-use sliders in the asset-store [settings UI pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=settings-ui-settings-ui).

eventsBasedObjects.description: Let users select a numerical value by dragging a slider.
eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelObjecisSlider

events.comment: This allows to detect a change of "intial value" on hot reload.
Create the child-object instances.
Create the label that is displayed over the thumb.
Pass the configuration to the behavior.

Children instances must be resized when the parent size change:
- background is resized to take the full dimensions of the parent
- the label is put back at the center of the bar

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

parameters: max(Background.BoundingBoxRight(), max(Label.BoundingBoxRight(), Thumb.BoundingBoxRight())) - min(Background.BoundingBoxLeft(), min(Label.BoundingBoxLeft(), Thumb.BoundingBoxLeft()))
max(Background.BoundingBoxBottom(), max(Label.BoundingBoxBottom(), Thumb.BoundingBoxBottom())) - min(Background.BoundingBoxTop(), min(Label.BoundingBoxTop(), Thumb.BoundingBoxTop()))

events.comment: The parent size is not defined in onCreate so it needs to be done here.

eventsFunctions.name: MaxValue

eventsFunctions.name: StepSize

eventsFunctions.description: Show (or hide) the label on the bar.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Time
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Converts seconds into standard time formats, such as HH:MM:SS.
description: Ideal for displaying timers on screen.
Formats included:
* HH:MM:SS
* HH:MM:SS.000 (displays milliseconds)

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: PanelObjecisButton
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: A button that can be customized.
description: The button can be customized with a background for each state and a label. It handles user interactions and a simple condition can be used to check if it is clicked.
There are ready-to-use buttons in the asset-store [menu buttons pack](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?initial-dialog=asset-store&asset-pack=menu-buttons-menu-buttons).

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: The finite state machine used internally by the button object.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ButtonFSM

events.comment: The "Validated" state only last one frame.
Make sure the cursor position is only checked once per frame.
Touches are always pressed, so ShouldCheckHovering doesn't matter.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is not used.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button was just clicked.
eventsFunctions.name: IsClicked

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the cursor is hovered over the button.
eventsFunctions.name: IsHovered

eventsFunctions.name: TouchId

eventsBasedObjects.description: A button that can be customized.
eventsBasedObjects.name: PanelObjecisButton

events.comment:
Create one background instance for of each state.
Only the instance for the current state is shown.
Place the label over the backgrounds.
Show the right background accordingly to the new state.

Children instances must be resized when the button size change:
- backgrounds for each state are resized to take the full dimensions of the button
- the label is put back at the center of the button

The scale is set back to 1 because it means that the parent instance has the same dimensions as the union of its children instances.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the button is currently being pressed with mouse or touch.
eventsFunctions.name: IsPressed

eventsFunctions.name: SetLabelText

eventsFunctions.description: Return the label text.
eventsFunctions.name: LabelText

eventsFunctions.name: CenterWithPaddingY

eventsFunctions.description: Center the label according to the button configuration. This is used in doStepPostEvents when the button is resized.
eventsFunctions.name: CenterLabel

eventsFunctions.name: Activate

eventsFunctions.name: IsActivated

propertyDescriptors.name: PressedLabelOffsetY

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: Bouh
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Controllers
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Add support for Controllers (or other controllers) to your game, giving access to information such as button presses, axis positions, trigger pressure, etc...
description: Add support for Controllers (or other controllers).
It gives access to:
- button presses
- axis positions and force
- trigger pressure
- configurable deadzone
- vibration
- automatic mappers for platformer characters and top-down movement
The Bomberman-like example handles 4 players with Controllers ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://goose-bomberman)).

eventsFunctions.description: Get the value of the pressure on a Controller trigger.
eventsFunctions.name: TriggerPressure

inlineCode: console.error('Parameter Controller identifier in expression: "Pressure on a Controller trigger", is not valid number, must be between 0 and 4.');
console.error('Parameter trigger is not valid in expression: "Pressure on a Controller trigger"');
//we need keep this condition because when use have not yet plug her controller we can't get the controller in the Controller variable.

eventsFunctions.description:
Get the force value of a Controller stick.
0 is stick on default position, 1 is at the maximum.
eventsFunctions.name: StickForce

inlineCode: console.error('Parameter Controller identifier is not valid in expression: "Value of a stick force"');
console.error('Parameter stick is not valid in expression: "Value of a stick force"');
//we need keep this condition because when use have not yet plug her controller we can't get the controller in the Controller variable.

eventsFunctions.description:
Get the rotation value of a Controller stick.
If the deadzone value is high, the angle value is rounded to main axes, left, left, up, down.
An zero deadzone value give a total freedom on the angle value.

inlineCode: console.error('Parameter Controller identifier is not valid in expression: "Value of a stick rotation"');

eventsFunctions.description: Set the deadzone for sticks of the Controller. The deadzone is an area for which movement on sticks won't be taken into account (instead, the stick will be considered as not moved). Deadzone is between 0 and 1, and is by default 0.2.
eventsFunctions.name: A_Set_deadzone
eventsFunctions.sentence: Set deadzone for sticks on Controller: _PARAM1_ to _PARAM2_

parameters.description: Deadzone for sticks, 0.2 by default (0 to 1)

A fast javascript implementation of simplex noise by Jonas Wagner
Based on a speed-improved simplex noise algorithm for 2D, 3D and 4D in Java.
Which is based on example code by Stefan Gustavson (stegu@itn.liu.se).
Better rank ordering method by Stefan Gustavson in 2012.

/** Deterministic simplex noise generator suitable for 2D, 3D and 4D spaces. */
* This involves some setup. You can save a few cpu cycles by reusing the same instance.
* @param {(() => number)|string|number} randomOrSeed A random number generator or a seed (string|number).
const random = typeof randomOrSeed == 'function' ? randomOrSeed : alea(randomOrSeed);
* Samples the noise field in 2 dimensions
let n0 = 0; // Noise contributions from the three corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y) * F2; // Hairy factor for 2D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y distances from the cell origin
// For the 2D case, the simplex shape is an equilateral triangle.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1; // Offsets for second (middle) corner of simplex in (i,j) coords
// A step of (1,0) in (i,j) means a step of (1-c,-c) in (x,y), and
// a step of (0,1) in (i,j) means a step of (-c,1-c) in (x,y), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G2; // Offsets for middle corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
const x2 = x0 - 1.0 + 2.0 * G2; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y) unskewed coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the three simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the three corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0); // (x,y) of grad3 used for 2D gradient
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1);
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to return values in the interval [-1,1].
* Samples the noise field in 3 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3; // Noise contributions from the four corners
// Skew the input space to determine which simplex cell we're in
const s = (x + y + z) * F3; // Very nice and simple skew factor for 3D
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z distances from the cell origin
// For the 3D case, the simplex shape is a slightly irregular tetrahedron.
// Determine which simplex we are in.
let i1, j1, k1; // Offsets for second corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
let i2, j2, k2; // Offsets for third corner of simplex in (i,j,k) coords
// A step of (1,0,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (1-c,-c,-c) in (x,y,z),
// a step of (0,1,0) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,1-c,-c) in (x,y,z), and
// a step of (0,0,1) in (i,j,k) means a step of (-c,-c,1-c) in (x,y,z), where
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G3; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G3; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z) coords
const x3 = x0 - 1.0 + 3.0 * G3; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the four simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the four corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad3[gi0] * x0 + grad3[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad3[gi0 + 2] * z0);
const gi1 = permMod12[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1]]] * 3;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad3[gi1] * x1 + grad3[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad3[gi1 + 2] * z1);
const gi2 = permMod12[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2]]] * 3;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad3[gi2] * x2 + grad3[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad3[gi2 + 2] * z2);
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad3[gi3] * x3 + grad3[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad3[gi3 + 2] * z3);
// Add contributions from each corner to get the final noise value.
// The result is scaled to stay just inside [-1,1]
* Samples the noise field in 4 dimensions
let n0, n1, n2, n3, n4; // Noise contributions from the five corners
// Skew the (x,y,z,w) space to determine which cell of 24 simplices we're in
const s = (x + y + z + w) * F4; // Factor for 4D skewing
const t = (i + j + k + l) * G4; // Factor for 4D unskewing
const X0 = i - t; // Unskew the cell origin back to (x,y,z,w) space
const x0 = x - X0; // The x,y,z,w distances from the cell origin
// For the 4D case, the simplex is a 4D shape I won't even try to describe.
// To find out which of the 24 possible simplices we're in, we need to
// determine the magnitude ordering of x0, y0, z0 and w0.
// Six pair-wise comparisons are performed between each possible pair
// of the four coordinates, and the results are used to rank the numbers.
// simplex[c] is a 4-vector with the numbers 0, 1, 2 and 3 in some order.
// Many values of c will never occur, since e.g. x>y>z>w makes x<z, y<w and x<w
// impossible. Only the 24 indices which have non-zero entries make any sense.
// We use a thresholding to set the coordinates in turn from the largest magnitude.
// Rank 2 denotes the second largest coordinate.
// Rank 1 denotes the second smallest coordinate.
// The integer offsets for the second simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the third simplex corner
// The integer offsets for the fourth simplex corner
// The fifth corner has all coordinate offsets = 1, so no need to compute that.
const x1 = x0 - i1 + G4; // Offsets for second corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x2 = x0 - i2 + 2.0 * G4; // Offsets for third corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x3 = x0 - i3 + 3.0 * G4; // Offsets for fourth corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
const x4 = x0 - 1.0 + 4.0 * G4; // Offsets for last corner in (x,y,z,w) coords
// Work out the hashed gradient indices of the five simplex corners
// Calculate the contribution from the five corners
n0 = t0 * t0 * (grad4[gi0] * x0 + grad4[gi0 + 1] * y0 + grad4[gi0 + 2] * z0 + grad4[gi0 + 3] * w0);
const gi1 = (perm[ii + i1 + perm[jj + j1 + perm[kk + k1 + perm[ll + l1]]]] % 32) * 4;
n1 = t1 * t1 * (grad4[gi1] * x1 + grad4[gi1 + 1] * y1 + grad4[gi1 + 2] * z1 + grad4[gi1 + 3] * w1);
const gi2 = (perm[ii + i2 + perm[jj + j2 + perm[kk + k2 + perm[ll + l2]]]] % 32) * 4;
n2 = t2 * t2 * (grad4[gi2] * x2 + grad4[gi2 + 1] * y2 + grad4[gi2 + 2] * z2 + grad4[gi2 + 3] * w2);
const gi3 = (perm[ii + i3 + perm[jj + j3 + perm[kk + k3 + perm[ll + l3]]]] % 32) * 4;
n3 = t3 * t3 * (grad4[gi3] * x3 + grad4[gi3 + 1] * y3 + grad4[gi3 + 2] * z3 + grad4[gi3 + 3] * w3);
n4 = t4 * t4 * (grad4[gi4] * x4 + grad4[gi4 + 1] * y4 + grad4[gi4 + 2] * z4 + grad4[gi4 + 3] * w4);
// Sum up and scale the result to cover the range [-1,1]
* This is exported only for (internal) testing purposes.
* Do not rely on this export.
The ALEA PRNG and masher code used by simplex-noise.js
is based on code by Johannes Baagøe, modified by Jonas Wagner.
See alea.md for the full license.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CarMovement
description: This extension allows to move objects on Bézier curve paths.
- Paths can be built dynamically or from predetermined paths in SVG format.
- A behavior moves objects in a given duration a bit like the Tween extension does.
- Another behavior moves objects using a speed and an acceleration.
- Expressions give access to the path trajectory values for more complex movements.
This extension can be used to:
- Move enemies that follow a pattern
- Animate decorations
A collection of [small examples](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://Car-movement) shows how to use this extension.
2 examples use it:
- a 3D racing game ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://3d-racing-game))
- a Zuma-like ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://smoothy))

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Move objects on Car paths at a given speed.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: CARMovement

events.comment: Update speed
Update the position on the path (the current length) with a Verlet integration.
It's useful to know which way to look at when the speed reached 0.

eventsFunctions.description: Change the path followed by an object.
eventsFunctions.name: SetPath
eventsFunctions.sentence: _PARAM0_ follow the path: _PARAM2_ repeated _PARAM3_ times and loop: _PARAM4_

parameters.longDescription: The path can be define with the "Append curve" action.
parameters.name: PathName

eventsFunctions.description: Change the path followed by an object to reach a position.
eventsFunctions.fullName: Follow a path to a position
eventsFunctions.name: SetPathTo
eventsFunctions.sentence: _PARAM0_ follow the path _PARAM2_ repeated _PARAM3_ times to reach _PARAM5_ ; _PARAM6_ and loop: _PARAM4_

events.comment: When the path is close or empty, there is no way to reach a destination

parameters: AngleBetweenPositions(Object.X(), Object.Y(), GetArgumentAsNumber("DestinationX"), Object.Y() + (GetArgumentAsNumber("DestinationY") - Object.Y()) / Object.Behavior::PathSpeedScaleY()) - AngleBetweenPositions(0, 0, Object.Behavior::PathEndX(),  Object.Behavior::PathEndY() / Object.Behavior::PathSpeedScaleY())

DistanceBetweenPositions(Object.X(), Object.Y(), GetArgumentAsNumber("DestinationX"), Object.Y() + (GetArgumentAsNumber("DestinationY") - Object.Y()) / Object.Behavior::PathSpeedScaleY()) / DistanceBetweenPositions(0, 0, Object.Behavior::PathEndX(), Object.Behavior::PathEndY() / Object.Behavior::PathSpeedScaleY()) / GetArgumentAsNumber("RepetitionCount")

parameters.longDescription: The path can be define with the "Append curve" action.
parameters.name: PathName

eventsFunctions.description: the length between the trajectory origin and the current position without counting the loops.

eventsFunctions.name: Loop

eventsFunctions.description: the length between the trajectory origin and the current position counting the loops.
eventsFunctions.name: PositionOnPath
eventsFunctions.sentence: the length from the trajectory origin counting the loops

eventsFunctions.name: SetPositionOnPath
